author: @user-we1wz7wq3x
text: Very good content! I'm strugling to understand how can I do cross-validation before using over or undersampling; I'm using method cross_validate in sklearn.model_selection; it takes the dataset (with train+validation data), and for instance cv=5; it'll do the 5 splits, training the model on 4 of them and evaluating on the one that was left out of training. I don't see how can I implement over/undersampling, as it's a built-in method. Only option I see would be creating a "CV splitter", but it doesn't seem to me that that will work, as it seems to only change what goes into train and what goes into validation.

author: @theconstantchange
text: today i am truly happy to know that i am not the only one who has problem with 100s of different classification error metrics. JUST LOOK AT THE CONFUSION MATRIX. That's the best answer.  Your BRAIN is capable enough to understand the subtleties from the matrix. I had a very similar experience with SORTING algorithm. Some data scientist guy somewhere thinks he is too smart just coz he knows some sorting algorithm and rejected me. Maybe i am glad he did. I wouldn't want to work in a place where data scientists assessed based on sorting algorithms. Josh thanks a lot. You're my hero.

author: @pdkovacs
text: Thanks a lot for this, Josh! Even though live-streams may not be as polished as edited videos (and I guess nobody gives a damn about this difference except you :-) ), the recapitulation parts are very useful for people like me, who need topics to be presented from slightly different perspectives so these topics are properly understood. Despite the easy looking presentation (which helps a lot in understanding the basic idea), these still seem pretty complex stuff to me, which require some more depths/view-points in presentation after introduced at a simplified level.

text: Hi Josh, can you please make a video for Lod score Z = log of the odds (marker and condition co-segregate with a probability of theta of recombination) / (results are due to chance)? Being able to watch a BAM BAM BAM video of yours on this topic would help me so much. Thanks a lot!
